content.text: Define acceleration
Describe the motion of the cyclist in the time between:
1. time \(= 0\) and time \(= 15\mathrm{s}\)
2. time \(= 15\mathrm{s}\) and time \(= 30\mathrm{s}\)
3. time \(= 30\mathrm{s}\) and time \(= 40\mathrm{s}\)
Calculate, for the 40 s journey:
1. the average speed
average speed =   .........
2. the maximum speed
maximum speed =   .........
Fig. 1.1 shows the distance-time graph for the journey of a cyclist
State one advantage and one disadvantage of using a wind turbine as a source of electrical energy
advantage
disadvantage

The wind blows at a speed of \(16\mathrm{m / s}\) towards the turbine blades. In one second, a volume of \(24 000\mathrm{m}^3\) of air passes through the circular area swept out by the blades. The density of air is \(1.3\mathrm{kg / m}^3\)
Calculate:
1. the mass of air that passes through the circular area swept out by the blades in 1.0 s
2. the kinetic energy of the mass of air that passes through the area swept out by the blades
kinetic energy =   .........
Suggest why some of the kinetic energy of the air that passes through the circular area swept out by the blades is **not** converted into electrical energy
Fig. 2.1 shows a wind turbine
An object is moving in a straight line at constant speed
State **three** ways in which a force may change the motion of the object
Fig. 3.1 shows an object suspended from two ropes. The weight of the object is \(360 \text{N}\). The magnitude of the tension in each rope is \(T\)
In the space below, determine the tension \(T\) by drawing a vector diagram of the forces acting on the object
State the scale you have used
scale
T =
The height \(h\) indicates a value of the atmospheric pressure
State what is contained in the space labelled S
On a particular day the atmospheric pressure is \(1.02 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\). The density of mercury is \(13 600 \text{kg} / \text{m}^{3}\)
Calculate the value of \(h\) indicated by the barometer
h =
The tube containing mercury is now tilted so that it makes an angle of \(10^{\circ}\) with the vertical. After tilting, there continues to be a space above the mercury in the tube
State and explain whether the vertical height of mercury in the tube is smaller, the same, or greater than the value calculated in (a)(ii)
Fig. 4.1 shows a mercury barometer. The tube containing the mercury is vertical
Another mercury barometer in the same room at the same time shows a lower value of \(h\) than the barometer in (a)
Suggest and explain a reason for the lower value
State the values of the _fixed points_ of a temperature scale
The graduations on a liquid-in-glass thermometer are equally spaced
For the equal spacing of the graduations to be correct, state:
1. an assumption that is made about the liquid in the thermometer
2. an assumption that is made about the structure of the thermometer
Liquid-in-glass thermometer A has a greater range than liquid-in-glass thermometer B
State **one** way the design of thermometer A is different from thermometer B
Liquid-in-glass thermometer C has a greater sensitivity than liquid-in-glass thermometer D
State **one** way the design of thermometer C is different from thermometer D
In the space provided, draw a labelled diagram of a thermocouple thermometer
Suggest when a thermocouple thermometer is more suitable than a liquid-in-glass thermometer
State the main process by which thermal energy is transferred to the air in all parts of the room
Calculate the time it takes for this heater to raise the temperature of the air in the room from \(8.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(15.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
State two reasons why the time calculated in (b)(i) is smaller than the actual time taken to raise the temperature of the air in the room from \(8.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(15.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
The heater has a power of \(1.5 \text{kW}\). The air in the room has a mass of \(65 \text{kg}\). The specific heat capacity of air is \(720 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\)
An electrical heater is placed on the floor of a room in a house. The heater is switched on
In Fig. 7.1, the small circles represent molecules. The arrows refer to the change of state from the arrangement of molecules on the left to the arrangement of molecules on the right
Complete the following by writing solid, liquid or gas in each of the blank spaces
Explain, in terms of the forces between their molecules, why gases expand more than solids when they undergo the same rise in temperature
A cylinder of volume \(0.012 \text{m}^3\) contains a compressed gas at a pressure of \(1.8 \times 10^6 \text{Pa}\)
A valve is opened and all the compressed gas escapes from the cylinder into the atmosphere
The temperature of the gas does not change
Calculate the volume that the escaped gas occupies at the atmospheric pressure of \(1.0 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\)
draw the wavefronts of the wave that passes into the air
draw arrows to show the direction of travel of the refracted wave
label the angle of incidence \(i\) and the angle of refraction \(r\)
The speed of the light wave in air is \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\). The refractive index of the ice is 1.3
On Fig. 8.1:
Calculate the speed of the light wave in the ice
Fig. 8.1 shows parallel wavefronts of a light wave in ice. The wavefronts are incident on a boundary with air
Calculate the resistance of the thermistor when the p.d. across it is 7.0 V
resistance =   .........
In Table 9.1, tick the boxes that indicate the effect on the resistances of the resistor and of the thermistor when the p.d. across them is increased from 0 to 7.0 V
the current from the supply
current =   .........
the energy transferred from the supply in 5.0 minutes
The thermistor and the resistor are connected in **parallel** to a 7.0 V supply
Calculate:
Fig. 9.1 shows current-potential difference (p.d.) graphs for a resistor and for a thermistor
The electrical energy produced by a power station is transmitted over long distances at a very high voltage
Explain why a very high voltage is used
The primary coil P has 4000 turns and an input of 120V. The secondary coil S has an output of 9.0V
Calculate the number of turns in the secondary coil
State a suitable material for the core of the transformer
Fig. 10.1 represents a transformer
One isotope of iridium-194 is represented by
This isotope decays by \(\beta \)-emission to a stable isotope of platinum (Pt)
Complete the nuclide equation for this decay
The half-life of iridium-194 is 19 hours. A sample of iridium-194 has an initial count-rate of 1100 counts/min
Calculate the count-rate from this sample after 38 hours
count-rate =   .........
State two ways in which \(\gamma \)-emission differs from \(\beta \)-emission
